event: Earliest known Archaic period inhabitants settle on the island of Hispaniola.
Taíno culture develops on the island, becoming the dominant indigenous group.
Christopher Columbus lands on Hispaniola during his first voyage; La Navidad settlement founded.
Bartholomew Columbus founds Santo Domingo, the oldest permanent European settlement in the Americas.
Treaty of Ryswick divides Hispaniola; western third (now Haiti) ceded to France, rest remains Spanish.
Treaty of Basel cedes the entire island to France.
Spanish regain control of eastern Hispaniola (Santo Domingo).
Santo Domingo declares independence from Spain as the Republic of Spanish Haiti.
Haitian forces under Jean-Pierre Boyer occupy Santo Domingo; unify island under Haitian rule.
Dominican Republic declares independence from Haiti on February 27.
President Pedro Santana returns the country to Spanish colonial rule.
Restoration War ends; Dominican Republic regains independence from Spain.
U.S. military occupies the Dominican Republic to stabilize political unrest and debt issues.
U.S. ends occupation; Horacio Vásquez elected president.
Rafael Trujillo seizes power, begins brutal dictatorship lasting over 30 years.
Trujillo assassinated; political instability follows.
Civil war and second U.S. intervention to prevent communist takeover.
Joaquín Balaguer elected president; begins era of authoritarian rule.
Democratic elections resume; peaceful transfer of power to opposition.
Leonel Fernández elected, ushering in new era of economic modernization.
New constitution enacted with expanded presidential powers and rights protections.
Luis Abinader elected president; manages COVID-19 pandemic and economic recovery efforts.
